sentence.text: Auditory neuropathy is a muscle organ development of hearing loss that constitutes a change in the conduct of the auditory stimulus by the involvement of inner hair cells or auditory nerve synapses.

At present, four loci associated with non‑syndromic auditory neuropathy have been mapped: Autosomal recessive deafness‑9 [DFNB9; the otoferlin (synaptic vesicle exocytosis) gene] and autosomal recessive deafness‑59 [DFNB59; the pejvakin (biological_process) gene], associated with autosomal recessive inheritance; the autosomal dominant auditory neuropathy gene [AUNA1; the diaphanous‑3 (cytoskeleton organization) gene]; and AUNX1, linked to chromosome X.
synaptic vesicle exocytosis gene mutations exert a significant role in auditory neuropathy.

The identification of genetic alterations responsible for auditory neuropathy is one of the challenges contributing to understand the molecular bases of the different phenomuscle organ developments of hearing loss.

Thus, the present study aimed to investigate molecular changes in the synaptic vesicle exocytosis gene in patients with auditory neuropathy, and to develop a DNA chip for the molecular diagnosis of auditory neuropathy using mass spectrometry for genotyping.

Genetic alterations were investigated in 47 patients with hearing loss and clinical diagnosis of auditory neuropathy, and the c.35delG mutation in the gap junction-mediated intercellular transport gene was identified in three homozygous patients, and the heterozygous parents of one of these cases.
